It owns a majority stake in UC Rusal (48.13%{{Cite web|url=http://www.rusal.ru/en/about/facts/|title=Facts and Figures|website=www.rusal.ru|accessdate=2 June 2017}}) and in EuroSibEnergo. EN+ also holds interests in SMR, one of the world's largest [[ferromolybdenum]] producers.  In 2017, it reported adjusted core earnings of $2.3 billion, on revenues totaling $9.8 billion.{{Cite news|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/russia-en-idUSL5N1H72UO|title=Russian tycoon Deripaska's En+ says 2016 core earnings $2.3 bln|date=18 April 2017|agency=[[Reuters]]|accessdate=2 June 2017}} In November 2017 En+ listed on the London Stock Exchange. === Metals and mining === ====RUSAL==== [[Rusal|United Company RUSAL]] is the world's second largest aluminium company. It was the largest until it was overtaken by [[China Hongqiao Group]] in 2015. UC RUSAL accounts for almost 7% of the world's primary aluminium output and 7% of the world's alumina production. The company employs over 63 000 in 20 countries on five continents. In order to ensure a stable supply of alumina to its smelters, several mergers and acquisitions were accomplished by RUSAL under Deripaska's guidance. At the beginning of the 2000s, RUSAL acquired bauxite mines in [[Guinea]], a country with the world's largest bauxite reserves. Subsequently, RUSAL acquired a stake in an alumina refinery in [[Australia]]. At Deripaska's behest, in 2007, RUSAL, [[SUAL Group]], one of the world's top 10 aluminum producers; and [[Glencore|Glencore International AG]], the Swiss natural resources group, merged their assets to form United Company RUSAL, the world's largest aluminum and alumina producer.{{cite news|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-russia-deripaska-profile-idUSTRE51L1IH20090222|title=FACTBOX: Who is Oleg Deripaska?|date=22 February 2009|accessdate=14 January 2016|agency=Reuters}} After the merger with [[Glencore]], bauxite and alumina assets in [[Jamaica]], Italy and Ireland were added to RUSAL's portfolio. These transactions converted RUSAL from a company with few supplies of the raw material bauxite into a vertically integrated corporation.{{cite web|title=Без партнеров|url=http://www.vedomosti.ru/newspaper/articles/2004/10/18/bez-partnerov|publisher=vedomosti.ru|accessdate=14 January 2016}} In parallel, Deripaska invested significantly in the operational improvement of smelters inside Russia. He said, "We consolidated the industry, and located bauxites that do not exist in Russia. We established the company that became the leader of industry in less than twelve years. But to become the number one alumimium producer in the world, we had to improve our operations practice. To apply the best practices in the world, we looked at Toyota, which had utilized a precise, deep and well thought-through process for almost thirty years of operations."{{cite web|url=http://www.rusal.ru/upload/uf/573/PROSPECTUS.pdf|title=United Company RUSAL Limited|publisher=RUSAL|accessdate=3 June 2017}} Deripaska himself has been an active supporter Japanese production efficiencies made popular by the "[[The Toyota Way|Toyota Way]]." RUSAL smelters have adopted the concept of ''[[kaizen]]'', which means continuous improvement and involves training workers in standardized production techniques. "It's important to change both the company’s mind set and reporting lines," Deripaska said. "Instead of top-down management, you should understand everything is in the hands of your operator and empower that operator to drive efficiencies and improvements directly on the factory floor." Under Deripaska's leadership, RUSAL constructed and commissioned Khakas aluminium smelter outside of Sayanogorsk in Russian Siberia. The Khakas facility was the first aluminium smelter built in post-Soviet Russia (since 1985). The smelter, with an annual capacity of 300,000 tonnes, is currently one of the most technologically advanced in the world{{Cite web|url=http://www.theguardian.com/business/2006/oct/22/theobserver.observerbusiness9|title=Simon Caulkin: The world's most modern plant - and it's in Siberia|last=Caulkin|first=Simon|date=22 October 2006|website=the Guardian|language=en|access-date=16 August 2018}}. The company also undertook large-scale modernization projects at a number of its facilities, including the Bratsk, Krasnoyarsk and Irkutsk aluminium smelters.{{cite web|title=HKUST IAS - UC RUSAL President's Forum|url=http://ias.ust.hk/ucrusal/2010/transcript.html|publisher=ias.ust.hk|accessdate=14 January 2016}} In the middle of the financial crisis, Deripaska returned in 2009 to RUSAL as CEO to lead the company through the debt restructuring process. "I worked 16-hour days. We were in default, although none of the parties involved wanted to call it default." As part of contingency measures, Deripaska cut costs at RUSAL by 25% in 2009. By December 2009, Deripaska reached a final agreement with over 70 Russian and international lenders to refinance US$17 billion of debt. In 2017, Rusal issued two [[Eurobond]]s to finance its debts. The first one, worth $600 million, was issued in February{{Cite news|url= http://aluminiuminsider.com/rusal-prices-initial-eurobond |title=Rusal Prices Initial Eurobond |date=30 January 2017|work=Aluminium Insider| accessdate =2 June 2017}}, followed by the second one in April, worth $500 million.{{Cite web|url= https://www.ft.com/content/1084218c-2cdc-355b-a52f-7887fb4aea59|title=Rusal profit amid rebound in aluminium prices|work =Financial Times |accessdate=2 June 2017}} Also in February, plans were announced to sell 10 billion yuan worth of seven-year onshore bonds to finance purchases in China. This made Rusal the first foreign company to offer [[panda bonds]] on the [[Shanghai Stock Exchange]].{{Cite news |url= http://www.scmp.com/business/companies/article/2069488/aluminium-giant-rusal-plans-10-billion-yuan-panda-bond-issue|title=Rusal plans 10 billion yuan panda bond issue in Shanghai|work=South China Morning Post|date=9 February 2017|accessdate=2 June 2017}} The company also agreed on a pre-export finance mechanism with international lenders worth $1.7 billion for debt refinancing.{{Cite news|url=http://aluminiuminsider.com/rusal-negotiates-us1-7-bn-pxf-debt-facility |title=Rusal Negotiates US$1.7 BN PXF Debt Facility |date=26 May 2017|work=Aluminium Insider|accessdate=2 June 2017}} In 2013, Deripaska was awarded the "Aluminium Industry Ambassador Award" in the ''[[Metal Bulletin]]'' Awards for Excellence for his "great influence within the global aluminium industry and the wider market".{{cite web|title=Winners of Metal Bulletin's awards for aluminium excellence 2013|url=http://www.metalbulletin.com/Article/3256866/Search/Winners-of-Metal-Bulletins-awards-for-aluminium-excellence.html|work=[[Metal Bulletin]]|accessdate=14 January 2016}} Deripaska stepped down from RUSAL in May 2018 the day after seven board members and the chief executive resigned. The move was part of an effort to get U.S. sanctions removed from the company.{{cite web|title=Sanctioned Tycoon Deripaska Resigns as Director of His Firm Rusal|url=https://www.nytimes.com/reuters/2018/05/25/business/25reuters-usa-russia-sanctions-rusal.html|website=[[The New York Times]]|date=25 May 2018|access-date=27 May 2018|agency=Reuters|last1=Devitt|first1=Polina|last2=Voronova|first2=Tatiana|last3=Korsunskaya|first3=Darya|last4=Lowe|first4=Christian|editor-last=Anantharaman|editor-first=Muralikumar}} ===Energy=== ==== EuroSibEnergo ==== Oleg Deripaska owns a 100% stake in EuroSibEnergo, the world's largest private [[hydrogeneration]] company and the largest private power company in Russia.{{Cite web|title=EuroSibEnergo (Russia): Global Sustainable Electricity Partnership|url=http://www.globalelectricity.org/en/index.jsp?p=324|website=www.globalelectricity.org|accessdate=13 January 2016|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160207221639/http://www.globalelectricity.org/en/index.jsp?p=324|archive-date=7 February 2016|dead-url=yes|df=dmy-all}} It controls and manages 18 power plants with a combined installed energy capacity of 19.5 GW, including 15 GW provided by hydrogeneration. The company produces approximately 9% of all electricity in [[Russia]] and is also the leader in the Siberian energy market, with a market share totaling 41%. Some of EuroSibEnergo's key clients include the largest aluminum plants in Russia. The company owns large fuel resources, which satisfy over 85% of the coal needs of its thermal power and boiler plants. Its coal reserves amount to 1.26 billion tons, with annual coal production exceeding 12 million tons. Deripaska's En+ Group, of which EuroSibEnergo is a subsidiary, is investing in a joint venture with China's largest [[hydroelectric power]] generation company [[China Yangtze Power]] Co to build new power plants in Siberia, primarily hydroelectric ones, with a total capacity of up to 10 GWt.{{Cite web| title = China Three Gorges, En+ eye projects in Russia|url=http://www.chinadailyasia.com/business/2015-10/30/content_15337032.html|work=[[China Daily Asia]]|date=30 October 2015|accessdate=13 January 2016}} ===Machinery=== ====Russian Machines==== Russian Machines corporation was established in 2005 and unites Oleg Deripaska's machine building assets. It comprises industrial and engineering assets in the following industries: automotive OEM (GAZ Group), automotive components (RM-Systems), rail industry (RM Rail), aircraft OEM (Aviacor), road construction (RM-Terex) and agricultural machinery (AGCO-RM).{{Cite web|title=GAZ Group: Private Company Information |url= https://www.bloomberg.com/research/stocks/private/snapshot.asp?privcapid=8954451|work=[[Businessweek]]|accessdate=13 January 2016}} Russian Machines Corporation manages 24 facilities located across 12 regions in Russia. ====GAZ Group==== In 2000, Deripaska started acquiring machine building assets. His first acquisition was [[Nizhny Novgorod]]-based Gorkovsky Automobile Plant (GAZ), which was previously a government-run company. In 2005, [[GAZ Group]] was established by combining the businessman's machine building assets.{{Cite web|title=Russian GAZ Starts Chrysler Sebring Based Siber Production|url=http://www.carscoops.com/2008/07/russian-gaz-starts-chrysler-sebring.html|work=CarScoops|accessdate=13 January 2016|date=28 July 2008}} The Russian automotive conglomerate, GAZ Group, comprises 18 manufacturing facilities in eight regions of Russia, as well as sales and service organizations. GAZ Group produces light and medium commercial vehicles, heavy trucks, buses, cars, road construction equipment, power units, and automotive components. ====Airports==== Basel Aero, a joint venture between Changi Airports International, Basic Element and Sberbank of Russia, is a company-operator the [[Sochi International Airport|Sochi]], [[Krasnodar International Airport|Krasnodar]] and [[Anapa Airport|Anapa airports]].{{Cite web|title=Sochi airport prepares for Winter Olympics - Airport World Magazine|url=http://www.airport-world.com/news/general-news/2923-sochi-airport-prepares-for-winter-olympics.html|website=www.airport-world.com|accessdate=13 January 2016}} These airports handle more than 7% of the total passenger flow in Russia.{{Cite web|title=Behind the scenes as Sochi Airport warms up for the 2014 Winter Olympic Games|url=http://www.airport-technology.com/features/featuresochi-airport-winter-olympic-games-technology-4160035/|website=Airport Technology |accessdate=13 January 2016}} Sochi International Airport was the main gateway to Sochi [[2014 Winter Olympics]] and successfully serviced the guests and participants of the Games. In October 2014, Sochi was granted [[open skies]] status, meaning that any foreign carrier may pick up and drop off passengers and cargo with no restrictions on aircraft type, frequency, and regardless of interstate agreements.{{Cite web|title=Sochi International Airport: Russia under wide Open Skies|url=http://www.basel.ru/en/in_focus/baselaero_23_03_2015/|work=basel.ru|accessdate=13 January 2016|date=23 March 2015|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160208170115/http://www.basel.ru/en/in_focus/baselaero_23_03_2015/|archive-date=8 February 2016|dead-url=yes|df=dmy-all}} ===Financial services=== Deripaska personally holds 10% of [[Ingosstrakh]]'s ordinary shares. The company is a leading insurer of complex risks such as [[Marine insurance|insurance]] for ship owners, ship hull insurance, insurance against aviation and space-related risks, and insurance of transportation companies. Ingosstrakh has 83 branches in Russia and the company's offices operate in 220 Russian towns and cities.{{Cite web|title=Deripaska Insurer's Volkov Says Ingosstrakh to Lease Out Planes|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2010-11-22/deripaska-insurer-s-volkov-says-ingosstrakh-to-lease-out-planes| work =Bloomberg |accessdate=13 January 2016|first=Ilya|last=Khrennikov|date=22 November 2010}} ===Agribusiness=== Oleg Deripaska fully owns Kuban Agroholding, a massive [[agribusiness]] in southern Russia. The company integrates two dairy farms, а 16,000 pig capacity breeding complex, three [[Grain elevator|elevators]] with non-recurrent grain storage capacity of more than 270,000 tonnes, three-seed plants, a sugar factory and the Sunrise horse breeding farm, specializing in the breeding of English [[thoroughbred]] horses. It is one of the top-20 largest agribusinesses and top-5 most efficient land users in Russia.{{Cite journal|title=Russia's Kuban Agroholding launches slaughterhouses, hog farm| url=http://issuu.com/farmingmonthly/docs/february_2015_farming_monthly_natio/12?e=15147366/11395275|work=Farming Monthly|date=February 2015|accessdate=13 January 2016}} Kuban Agroholding is one of the few agrocompanies in Russia involved in [[embryo transfer]] technology that allows for the reproduction of high-yielding milk cows out of less productive recipients.{{Cite web|title=Interview: R&D and innovation are key in race to boost Russia's farm output|url=https://www.agra-net.com/agra/agra-europe/analysis/interview-rd-and-innovation-are-key-in-race-to-boost-russia-s-farm-output-467790.htm|work=Agra-net.com|accessdate=13 January 2016}} The company has gained significant media attention about its corn-seeding program, deploying several dozen corn brands selected by its genetic specialists. === Other roles === In 2004, Deripaska was appointed by the [[President of Russia]] to represent the country in the [[Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation]] [[Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation#APEC Business Advisory Council|Business Advisory Council]] (ABAC). He has been Chairman of ABAC Russia since 2007. Deripaska is the vice president of the [[Russian Union of Industrialists and Entrepreneurs]], chairman of the executive board of the Russian national committee of the [[International Chamber of Commerce]] and a member of the Competitiveness and Entrepreneurship Council, an agency of the Russian government.[http://www.deripaska.com/about-oleg-deripaska/biography Oleg Deripaska biodata] {{webarchive|url= https://web.archive.org/web/20110721132612/http://www.deripaska.com/about-oleg-deripaska/biography|date=21 July 2011}}. Retrieved 12 May 2012. He has been a permanent participant at [[World Economic Forum]] sessions since 2007, when RUSAL became a WEF strategic partner.{{Cite web|title=Oleg V. Deripaska|url=http://www.weforum.org/contributors/oleg-v-deripaska|publisher=[[World Economic Forum]]|accessdate=13 January 2016|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150404232416/http://www.weforum.org/contributors/oleg-v-deripaska|archive-date=4 April 2015|dead-url=yes|df=dmy-all}} In May 2007, [[Magna International]] chairman [[Frank Stronach]] announced that Deripaska was becoming a strategic partner in Magna.{{Cite web|url = http://www.reportonbusiness.com/servlet/story/RTGAM.20070510.wmagna10/BNStory/robNews/home|title = Russian billionaire buying Magna stake|date = 10 May 2007|work = The Globe and Mail |last = Keenan|first = Greg}} Deripaska is also a member of the International Council at [[Harvard University]]'s [[Belfer Center for Science and International Affairs]].{{Cite web|url=https://www.belfercenter.org/person/oleg-deripaska|title=Oleg Deripaska|publisher=Belfer Center for Science and International Affairs|accessdate=4 May 2017|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170405171539/https://www.belfercenter.org/person/oleg-deripaska|archivedate=5 April 2017|df=dmy-all}} Deripaska personally initiated construction of the Centre for Epidemic and Microbiological Research and Treatment in the Guinean [[Kindia Region|Kindia]] province. The Centre was designed and constructed by [[United Company RUSAL|RUSAL]] specialists with the assistance of [[Rospotrebnadzor]] scientists (RUSAL has invested $10 million).{{Cite web|url=http://africatimes.com/2017/05/22/ebola-2-0-lessons-learned-in-2014-may-not-suffice/|title=Ebola 2.0 – Lessons Learned in 2014 May Not Suffice|date=22 May 2017|website=Africa Times|accessdate=25 May 2017}} He sits on the board of trustees of the School of Business Administration, the School of Public Administration, and the School of Economics at [[Moscow State University]] as well as the School of Business Administration at [[St. Petersburg State University]]. Deripaska is a co-founder of the National Science Support Foundation and the National Medicine Fund. In 1999, he was awarded the [[Order of Friendship]], a state award of the [[Russian Federation]]. He was named businessman of the year in 1999, 2006, and 2007 by ''[[Vedomosti]]'', a Russian business daily. Deripaska also sits on the board of trustees of the [[Bolshoi Theatre]], and has financed [[ballet]] performances like ''[[Flames of Paris]]'', ''[[La Sylphide]]'', and ''[[Paquita]]'' as well as [[opera]]s like ''[[The Legend of the Invisible City of Kitezh and the Maiden Fevroniya]]'', ''[[Carmen]]'', and ''[[Wozzeck]]''.{{Cite web|url=http://www.forbes.ru/profile/oleg-deripaska|title=Олег Дерипаска|work=Forbes Russia|accessdate=13 January 2016}} ==Philanthropy== {{Advert section|date=February 2018}} ===Volnoe Delo=== In 1998, Deripaska established [[Volnoe Delo]], Russia's largest private charitable foundation.{{Cite news|url=https://www.europeanceo.com/profiles/oleg-deripaska-and-the-russian-aluminium-wars/|title=Oleg Deripaska and the Russian aluminium wars|access-date=25 May 2018|language=en-US}}{{Cite web|url=http://volnoe-delo.ru/en/|title=Volnoe Delo Foundation|website=volnoe-delo.ru|language=ru|access-date=25 May 2018}}[http://www.volnoe-delo.ru (20 April 2009): The Volnoe Delo Fund acknowledged as the largest contributor] {{ru icon}} The fund supports over 400{{cn|date=February 2018}} initiatives across Russia aimed at developing education and science, preserving spiritual and cultural heritage, and improving standards in public health.[http://www.volnoe-delo.ru/ Volnoe Delo Fund website] {{ru icon}}{{Cite web|url=https://www.heritagedaily.com/2016/08/darius-i-stele-found-in-ancient-town-of-phanagoria-in-russia/112378|title=Darius I stele found in ancient town of Phanagoria in Russia - HeritageDaily - Heritage & Archaeology News|website=www.heritagedaily.com|language=en-US|access-date=25 May 2018}}{{Cite news|url=https://www.huffingtonpost.co.uk/entry/billionaire-sochi-stray-dogs_n_4767912?guccounter=1|title=Billionaire Saves Sochi Stray Dogs!|date=11 February 2014|work=HuffPost UK|access-date=25 May 2018|language=en-GB}} It helps children, old people, talented youths, teachers, eminent scientists and other participants of the programs. Since 1998, Oleg Deripaska has invested more than [[Russian ruble|RUB]]10.6 billion{{cn|date=February 2018}} in more than 500 charity programs in 50 regions of Russia.{{Cite web|url=http://volnoe-delo.ru/en/|title=Volnoe Delo Foundation|website=volnoe-delo.ru|accessdate=13 January 2016}}{{additional citation|date=February 2018}} Volnoe Delo has supported research activities in the 2,550-year-old city of [[Phanagoria]] since 2004. More than $10 million has been allocated to Phanagoria fieldwork over the past 14 years.{{Cite news|url=https://popular-archaeology.com/article/darius-i-stele-found-in-ancient-town-of-phanagoria-in-russia/|title=Popular Archeology - Darius I stele found in ancient town of Phanagoria in Russia|work=Popular Archeology|access-date=25 May 2018|language=en-US}} Today, Phanagoria is one of the best-equipped archeological expeditions in Russia and has its own scientific and cultural center, cutting edge equipment and technology for above-ground and underwater excavation as well as a large team of specialists involved in the excavation process.{{Cite web|url=http://popular-archaeology.com/issue/06052014/article/ancient-naval-ram-found-in-phanagoria-reveals-history-of-popular-unrest-in-63-b-c|title=Ancient naval ram found in Phanagoria reveals history of popular unrest in 63 B.C.|work=Popular Archeology|accessdate=13 January 2016}} In 2014, Volnoe Delo foundation launched a programme on students' early career guidance and professional training—JuniorSkills.{{Cite web|url=http://volnoe-delo.ru/en/events/news/junior-skills/|title=Junior Skills|website=volnoe-delo.ru|accessdate=13 January 2016}} The first, pilot, championship on professional skills, JuniorSkills Hi-Tech, was held in the Urals city of [[Yekaterinburg]] in 2014, part of the nationwide championship on cross-industry blue-collar professions in high-tech WorldSkills. ===Climate change === Deripaska is one of the 16 global business leaders who drafted CEO Climate Policy Recommendations to [[G8]] Leaders, a document outlining the international business community's proposals to tackle [[global warming]]. The proposals were signed by more than 100 of the world's leading corporations and handed to the [[Prime Minister of Japan]] [[Yasuo Fukuda]] on 20 June 2008. The G8 leaders discussed the recommendations during the summit in Japan on 7–9 July 2008. The process was coordinated by the [[World Economic Forum]] in collaboration with the [[World Business Council for Sustainable Development]].{{cite web|url=http://www.weforum.org/en/initiatives/ghg/index.htm|title=World Economic Forum; Climate Change; CEO Climate Policy Recommendations to G8 Leaders|publisher=World Economic Forum|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20101213183842/http://www.weforum.org/en/initiatives/ghg/index.htm|archivedate=13 December 2010|deadurl=yes|accessdate=14 May 2011|df=dmy-all}}
[http://www.basel.ru/en/media/news/200807/news_07_07_2008/ Expert magazine; "Zero Waste"; interview] {{dead link|date=June 2016|bot=medic}}{{cbignore|bot=medic}} Deripaska actively advocates cutting the global carbon footprint and calls for the creation of an enforcement mechanism with consequences for countries that do not reduce carbon-intensive emissions, such as those produced by coal-fired powerplants.{{Cite news|url=http://www.ft.com/intl/cms/s/0/b72f19fe-7432-11e5-a129-3fcc4f641d98.html|title=Deripaska warns about competitive risks from Paris climate deal|last=Sanderson|first=Henry|date=18 October 2015|work=Financial Times|accessdate=13 January 2016|last2=Clark|first2=Pilita|issn=0307-1766}} He also remains a strong advocate of a legally binding climate change deal, but has publicly voiced concern about the potential competitive impact of a [[Paris climate agreement]] and also about the absence of binding measures to curb each country's emissions in the near future. "Everyone is in favour; we just need to have more or less fair regulation. There shouldn't be any pockets where people can cheat the system. People shouldn't agree on something that creates another Kyoto protocol that creates nice polished statements", he told the ''Financial Times'' in January 2016. ===Other activities=== In February 2014, Deripaska financed the construction of makeshift kennels to house stray dogs that had been abandoned by construction workers after completing work on the [[Sochi Olympic Stadium|Sochi Olympic Village]]. Officials said the number of strays exceeded 2,000 and the animals presented a risk of [[rabies]], so they contracted out their extermination. Many of these dogs were saved and more were re-homed in a global adoption program that Deripaska created.{{cite news|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/europe/sochi-olympic-parks-condemned-stray-dogs-saved-by-russian-billionaire-9118727.html|title=Sochi Olympic Park's condemned stray dogs 'saved by Russian billionaire'|last=Withnall|first=Adam|date=10 February 2014|work=[[The Independent]]|accessdate=10 February 2014|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6NIpi8tqF?url=http://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/europe/sochi-olympic-parks-condemned-stray-dogs-saved-by-russian-billionaire-9118727.html|archivedate=11 February 2014|deadurl=yes|location=London|df=dmy}} ==Assisted FBI with Rescue of Levinson== Between mid-2008 and 2009, Deripaska helped the then-FBI Director [[Robert Mueller]] rescue a former FBI-agent [[Robert Levinson]], who disappeared in 2007 while working for the CIA in Iran. The then-FBI deputy director [[Andrew McCabe]] played key role in courting Deripaska. Agents secretly met Deripaska in hotels in Paris, Vienna, Budapest, Hungary, and Washington, convincing him to spend millions of his own dollars funding the FBI-supervised operation to Levinson. His participation was crucial, as he had close business ties in Iran, and because of economic sanctions imposed on Iran and other laws made it illegal for the FBI or any US citizen to spend any money in Iran. Deripaska's lawyer said he spent $25 million on a private search-and-rescue team that worked with Iranian contacts while monitored by the FBI. Deripaska managed to arrange the release of Levinson, but the U.S. State Department, then under [[Hillary Clinton]], blocked a deal for Levinson's return from going through. Robyn Gritz, the retired agent who supervised the Levinson case in 2009, said: "We tried to turn over every stone we could to rescue Bob, but every time we started to get close, the State Department seemed to always get in the way". “We were told at one point that the terms of Levinson’s release had been agreed to by Iran and the U.S. and included a statement by then-Secretary of State Hillary Clinton pointing a finger away from Iran. At the last minute, Secretary Clinton decided not to make the agreed-on statement.” The operation was ended in 2011, because FBI officials were concerned that Deripaska's Iranian contacts couldn't deliver with all the U.S. infighting. The FBI rewarded Deripaska for his help.{{cite news |url=http://thehill.com/opinion/white-house/387625-mueller-may-have-a-conflict-and-it-leads-directly-to-a-russian-oligarch |title=Mueller may have a conflict — and it leads directly to a Russian oligarch |publisher=''[[The Hill (newspaper)|The Hill]]'' |first=John |last=Solomon |date=14 May 2018}}{{cite news |url=http://www.nytimes.com/2013/12/14/world/middleeast/a-disappearing-american-spy-and-the-cia.html |title=A Disappearing Spy, and a Scandal at the C.I.A. |publisher=''The New York Times'' |first=Barry |last=Meier |date=13 December 2013}} == FBI recruitment attempt == According to anonymous sources cited by the 1 September 2018 [[New York Times]]′s report, Deripaska was twice approached by the U.S. government officials, including [[Bruce Ohr]], as part of the U.S. government wider FBI–led recruitment effort to obtain informers in the circle close to [[Vladimir Putin]]: in September 2015 and in September 2016.{{cite news |last1=Vogel |first1=Kenneth P. |last2=Rosenberg |first2=Matthew |title=Agents Tried to Flip Russian Oligarchs. The Fallout Spread to Trump. |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2018/09/01/us/politics/deripaska-ohr-steele-fbi.html |accessdate=2 September 2018 |work=The New York Times |date=1 September 2018 |language=en}} Ohr, then a [[United States Department of Justice]] official, was reported to have been in contact with the former employee of the [[British secret service]] MI6 [[Christopher Steele]], who later compiled the incriminating [[Trump dossier|dossiers]] on [[Donald Trump]], and discussed cultivating Deripaska, among others. In September 2015, Ohr and Steele met with Deripaska to discuss "connections between Russian organized crime and Mr. Putin’s government, as well as other issues, according to a person familiar with the events." Deripaska laughed them off and did not agree to a second meeting.{{cite news |url=https://www.zeit.de/news/2018-09/02/bericht-us-ermittler-wollten-oligarchen-deripaska-als-informanten-gewinnen-20180902-doc-18s9cd |title=Bericht: US-Ermittler wollten Oligarchen Deripaska als Informanten gewinnen |publisher=''[[Die Zeit]]'' |date=2 September 2018 |lang=de}}{{cite news |url=https://www.timesofisrael.com/report-us-investigators-probing-trump-sought-to-cultivate-russian-oligarchs/ |title=Report: US investigators probing Trump sought to cultivate Russian oligarchs |publisher=''[[The Times of Israel]]'' |date=3 September 2018}} Nevertheless, F.B.I. agents showed up unannounced at Deripaska's door in New York in September 2016. The attempts to turn Deripaska into an informant undertaken between 2014 and 2016 were unsuccessful, Deripaska notified the Russian authorities of the US efforts to recruit him. In September 2018, Russia's government accused the US of meddling in the country's affairs by attempting to recruit Russian citizens as agents for American security services.{{cite news |url=https://www.ft.com/content/57cbf8e4-af6f-11e8-8d14-6f049d06439c |title=Russia says US spy agencies attempting to interfere in its affairs |publisher=''Financial Times'' {{subscription required}} |first=Henry |last=Foy |date=3 September 2018}} ==Controversies== ===Cherney lawsuit=== [[Michael Cherney]] brought legal action against Deripaska in the [[Commercial Court (England and Wales)|Commercial Court]] of the [[High Court]] in London.{{cite news|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/europe/the-worlds-richest-russian-is-sued-for-3bn-in-london-437814.html|title=The world's richest Russian is sued for $3bn in London|work=The Independent|location=UK|date=25 February 2007|accessdate=14 May 2011|first=Andrew|last=Osborn}} Cherney sought a declaration that he was the beneficial owner of 20% of [[RUSAL]] stock which, he claimed, Deripaska held in trust for him. The claim was denied. On 3 May 2007, Justice Langley ruled that Deripaska had not been properly [[service of process|served]], and that the court had no [[jurisdiction]] to try the claim as Deripaska did not live in England or Wales.{{cite web|url=http://www.bailii.org/ew/cases/EWHC/Comm/2007/965.html|title=''Cherney v Deripaska'', 2007 EWHC 965 (Comm)|publisher=Bailii.org|accessdate=14 May 2011}} On 3 July 2008, Justice Christopher Clarke ruled that the case should be tried in England, although "the natural forum for this litigation is Russia", because, he held, "risks inherent in a trial in Russia...are sufficient to make England the forum in which the case can most suitably be tried in the interest of both parties and the ends of justice".{{cite web|url=http://www.bailii.org/ew/cases/EWHC/Comm/2008/1530.html|title=''Cherney v Deripaska'', 2008 EWHC 1530 (Comm)|publisher=Bailii.org|accessdate=14 May 2011}} On 22 July 2008, he granted Deripaska leave to appeal. The Court of Appeal of England and Wales refused the appeal on 31 July 2009.{{cite web|url= http://www.bailii.org/ew/cases/EWCA/Civ/2009/849.html|title=Deripaska v Cherney, 2009 EWCA Civ 849|publisher=Bailii.org|accessdate=14 May 2011}} At a June 2011 case management conference, the judge deferred a decision on whether Cherney would be allowed to give evidence by video link from Israel rather than appear in person. An outstanding arrest warrant issued by [[Interpol]] meant that the British would detain him if he travelled to the UK.Paul, Jonny. (23 June 2011) [http://www.jpost.com/International/Article.aspx?id=226187&R=R4 "British High Court to decide: Can Cherney testify by video?"] ''The Jerusalem Post''. 23 June 2011. Retrieved 12 May 2012.[http://www.interpol.int/public/Data/Wanted/Notices/Data/2009/42/2009_21842.asp "Wanted: Cherney, Michael"]{{dead link|date=September 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot|fix-attempted=yes}}. [[Interpol]], (14 October 2010) In late July 2011, the High Court ruled to allow Cherney to give evidence at the trial by video link from Israel, and also set trial for April 2012.{{cite news |url =http://www.thisislondon.co.uk/standard/article-23973334-the-gangster-a-billionaire-friend-of-mandelson-and-a-pound-23bn-row.do |title=The 'gangster', a billionaire friend of Mandelson and a £2.3bn row|work=Evening Standard|first=Paul|last=Cheston|date=28 July 2011|accessdate=8 August 2011| deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120222031121/http://www.thisislondon.co.uk/standard/article-23973334-the-gangster-a-billionaire-friend-of-mandelson-and-a-pound-23bn-row.do|archivedate=22 February 2012|df=dmy}} Deripaska denied that Cherney was owed any stake in RUSAL, and asserted payments made to Cherney had been for unavoidable "protection" at a time when violence was sweeping the region and posed an existential threat to any profitable business in the country. In an interview with ''The Telegraph'', Deripaska said he was one of the few who worked to clean up Russian industry and provided support to law enforcement agencies. However, in this early chaotic period paying protection money to criminal gangs was inescapable, as revealed in court testimony.{{Cite web|title=Oleg Deripaska: Why I paid crime gangs for protection| url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/finance/newsbysector/industry/mining/9218657/Oleg-Deripaska-Why-I-paid-crime-gangs-for-protection.html|work=The Telegraph |accessdate=13 January 2016}} In September 2012, Cherney terminated his UK lawsuit against Deripaska.{{cite news|url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/SB10000872396390444549204578022433469797910 |title=Suit Against Russian Billionaire Is Dropped|work=The Wall Street Journal|first1=Paul|last1=Sonne|first2=Alexander|last2=Kolyandr|date=27 September 2012|accessdate=7 November 2012}} === U.S. investigation=== In 2015, Deripaska filed a lawsuit against [[Morgan Stanley]], accusing the bank of using [[insider information]] to [[short (finance)|short sell]] the businessman's $1.5 billion investment in shares of Magma in 2008.{{Cite web|title=Morgan Stanley to face Russian tycoon's insider trading claims |url= http://in.reuters.com/article/morgan-stanley-trial-idINL1N12S3RO20151101|website=Reuters India|accessdate=13 January 2016}} In 2007, Deripaska's Veleron [[investment vehicle]] acquired stock in Canadian based [[Magna International]] through a $1.2 billion loan from [[BNP Paribas]], with Magna shares serving as [[collateral (finance)|collateral]].{{Cite web|title=Russian tycoon Oleg Deripaska sues Morgan Stanley|url=https://www.rt.com/business/320611-deripaska-rusal-bank-court/|website=RT International|accessdate=13 January 2016}} Morgan Stanley was involved in the deal through a swap agreement with BNP Paribas where the US bank assumed the risks of the loan in return for a fixed payment from Paribas.{{Cite web|title=Morgan Stanley Defeats Russian Tycoon’s Short-Selling Claims|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2015-11-13/morgan-stanley-defeats-russian-tycoon-s-short-selling-claims-igy8py53|website=Bloomberg.com|accessdate=13 January 2016|first=Bob|last=Van Voris|first2=Erik|last2=Larson}} In September 2008, Magna's stocks plummeted, hit by the global economic downturn. BNP issued a $93 million [[margin call]] to Veleron. Morgan Stanley, in turn, learned that Veleron was unlikely to meet the call and sold the stock short.{{Cite news|title=UPDATE 1-Morgan Stanley cleared in Russian tycoon's insider trading lawsuit|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/morgan-stanley-trial-idUSL1N1382UF20151113|newspaper=Reuters|date=13 November 2015|accessdate=13 January 2016}} Deripaska claimed that Morgan Stanley abused its duties and engaged in unlawful [[insider trading]] that resulted in significant financial damage to Veleron, estimated at $15 million to $25 million. A New York jury determined in November 2015 that Morgan Stanley had "acquired inside information and traded on it despite a duty to keep it confidential and not trade on it," finding as well that Morgan Stanley did not have the intent to [[defraud]] Veleron. Veleron strongly disagreed with and said it would file an appeal.{{when|date=June 2016}} In July 2006, whilst Deripaska was involved in a bid to buy the [[Daimler Chrysler]] Group, it was reported that the United States canceled his entry visa; the unnamed official declined to give a reason for the revoking of the visa. The ''[[Wall Street Journal]]'' reported that it could have been because Deripaska has been accused of having links to organized crime in Russia and cited as their sources two unnamed U.S. law enforcement officials.{{cite news|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/idUSN1143738620070511|title=U.S. revoked Deripaska visa – State Dep't official|first=Jim|last=Wolf|date=11 May 2007|agency=Reuters}} ''The New York Times'' reported on 27 August 2018 that the visa had been revoked on concerns Deripaska might attempt to launder money through real estate transactions.{{cite web|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2018/08/27/us/politics/bruce-ohr-trump-justice-department.html|title=Bruce Ohr Fought Russian Organized Crime. Now He’s a Target of Trump.|publisher=|accessdate=29 August 2018}} Deripaska had received a multiple-entry visa in 2005; a U.S. [[Federal Bureau of Investigation]] spokesman refused to comment. Lobbying on his behalf had been done by former Senate Republican leader and 1996 presidential candidate [[Bob Dole]] and his Alston & Bird law partners, Senate records show. Alston & Bird was paid about US$260,000 in 2005 for work on "Department of State visa policies and procedures" tied to Deripaska. In 2009, Deripaska was again allowed entry and visited the United States twice. ''The Wall Street Journal'' reported that according to two unnamed FBI administration officials, Deripaska had met with agents regarding a continuing criminal probe, the details of the probe were not known or reported. During Deripaska's visits, he met with leading management figures from investment banks [[Goldman Sachs]] and [[Morgan Stanley]]. The Aluminum company that Deripaska heads, [[United Company RUSAL]], was in preparations for an initial public offering. The easing of Deripaska's visa issues which were an issue for possible investors helped to reassure bankers. The State Department has never said why it revoked his visa and refused to comment on his 2009 visits. The visits were arranged outside of the usual process as the U.S. continues to have concerns about Deripaska's business associations. Deripaska has repeatedly denied a connection to any organized crime and said business rivals have caused the visa to be revoked by smearing him. When interviewed by the BBC in July 2009, Deripaska said that the authorities in the United States had been attempting to blackmail him by revoking his visa and thus affecting possible investors in a negative way and thereby hoping to push Deripaska into cooperating with them.{{cite news| url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/SB125687000832717809 | work=The Wall Street Journal | title=Deripaska Accused U.S. of Blackmail | date=30 October 2009}} ===Spanish investigation=== According to an article in ''[[El Mundo (Spain)|El Mundo]]'', Deripaska and [[Iskander Makhmudov]] (head of UGMK) were asked by Spanish police to answer questions in relation to a money-laundering enquiry.{{cite web|url=http://www.elmundo.es/papel/2010/03/21/mercados/23228430.html |title=Quiosco, El Mundo en ORBYT |work=El Mundo|location=Spain |accessdate=14 May 2011}} The Spanish state prosecutor's office subsequently confirmed Deripaska's interrogation.{{cite news| url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-1282571/Oligarch-friend-Peter-Mandelson-faces-cash-launder-quiz.html?ito=feeds-newsxml |work=Daily Mail | title=Oligarch friend of Mandelson faces cash launder quiz | date=30 May 2010 | location=London | first=Jason | last=Lewis}} While Deripaska has been interrogated previously as a witness in Spain and England and by the FBI in cases of [[money laundering]], he has never been charged with any crimes in those probes.{{cite news| url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/SB125685578903317087 | work=The Wall Street Journal | title=FBI Lets Barred Tycoon Visit U.S | first1=Evan | last1=Perez | first2=Gregory L. | last2=White | date=30 October 2009}} On 25 January 2010, the ''[[Financial Times]]'' published a story "Rusal: A lingering heat" exploring Deripaska's business relations with Sergei Popov and Anton Malevsky, alleged heads of Russian organized crime groups.{{cite web|url=http://www.ft.com/cms/s/0/70a1c458-09ff-11df-8b23-00144feabdc0.html?nclick_check=1 |title=/ Comment / Analysis – Rusal: A lingering heat |work=Financial Times |date=25 January 2010 |accessdate=14 May 2011}} Deripaska has accused Michael Chernoy of using Malevsky and the [[Izmaylovskaya gang|Izmailovskaya syndicate]] to extort US$250 million from him as part of a protection racket.{{cite news|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/uk/home-news/clash-of-the-oligarchs-1753022.html|title=Clash of the oligarchs|work=The Independent|location=UK|date=20 July 2009|accessdate=14 May 2011|first=Donald|last=MacIntyre}} However, Deripaska has himself been accused of having similar links to Malevsky, who, with his brother Andrei, owned a 10% stake in Deripaska's company. Deripaska denies the claims.Swinford, Steven, "Peter Mandelson oligarch Oleg Deripaska linked to mafia boss", ''The Sunday Times'' (London), 26 October 2008. In November 2011, Spain's High Court sent the criminal cases against Deripaska to the Russian General Prosecutor's office because the root of the cases is Russian.{{cite news|url=http://en.gazeta.ru/news/2011/11/25/a_3848274.shtml|title=Russian Tycoon Deripaska's case given to Russia's court by Spain|publisher=gazeta.ru|first=Darya|last=Ispolnova|date=25 November 2011|accessdate=28 November 2011}} ===Political relationships=== [[File:Vladimir Putin 19 March 2002-4.jpg|thumb|[[Vladimir Putin]] and Deripaska, 19 March 2002]] ====Vladimir Putin==== Deripaska is noted for his close ties with Russian President [[Vladimir Putin]]. Their relationship was visibly strained amidst Deripaska's financial struggles in 2009, but in a widely broadcast incident on Russian television, Putin visited a stalled cement factory owned by Deripaska and berated its management. He forced Deripaska to sign a contract promising to pay nearly $1 million in unpaid wages.{{cite news|last1=Oliphant|first1=Roland|title=Fifteen years of Vladimir Putin: in quotes|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/vladimir-putin/11588182/Fifteen-years-of-Vladimir-Putin-in-quotes.html|accessdate=25 May 2017|work=[[The Daily Telegraph]]|date=7 May 2015|language=en}}
{{cite news|last1=Reynolds|first1=Leda|title=ISIS beware: THIS is how hardman Russian President Vladimir Putin gets things DONE|url= http://www.express.co.uk/news/world/610552/ISIS-beware-THIS-is-how-hardman-Vladimir-Putin-gets-things-DONE|accessdate=25 May 2017|work=The Express| date=7 October 2015|language=en}} Their relationship recovered, however, and Deripaska has been described as "Putin's favorite [[Business magnate|industrialist]]".{{cite news|last1=Marcin|first1=Tim|title=Meet Oleg Deripaska, who allegedly worked with former Trump aide Paul Manafort to push Putin's views| url=http://www.newsweek.com/who-oleg-deripaska-paul-manafort-russian-putin-572157|accessdate=25 May 2017|work=Newsweek|date=22 March 2017|language=en}} [[United States diplomatic cables leak|Leaked U.S. diplomatic cables]] from 2006 described Deripaska as "among the 2-3 oligarchs Putin turns to on a regular basis" and "a more-or-less permanent fixture on Putin's trips abroad".{{cite news|last1= Horowitz| first1=Jeff|last2=Day|first2=Chad|title=AP findings on Trump associate's work for Russian oligarch|url=https://apnews.com/ba0027b4c29a4863b096d7216ee0ca58/ap-findings-trump-associates-work-russian-oligarch|accessdate=25 May 2017|agency=[[Associated Press]]|date=22 March 2017}} In an interview with ''[[The Globe and Mail]]'', Tye Burt, who knows Deripaska and is the CEO of [[Kinross Gold]] said that, "I believe Russia recognizes Oleg's major role in building a renewed economic base in a broad range of domestic businesses and rejuvenating ailing companies and infrastructure." ====Nathaniel Rothschild and Peter Mandelson==== Deripaska is a friend of [[Nathaniel Philip Rothschild|Nathaniel Rothschild]], a major investor in both [[Glencore]] and [[United Company RUSAL]]. Together Deripaska and Rothschild hosted [[George Osborne]] and [[Peter Mandelson]] on Deripaska's yacht in [[Corfu]] in the summer of 2008. {{cite news|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/opinion/leading-articles/leading-article-the-flawed-judgement-of-a-shadow-chancellor-968549.html|title=Leading article: The flawed judgement of a shadow Chancellor|date=22 October 2008|work=The Independent|location=UK|accessdate=23 November 2009}} Osborne was then Shadow [[Chancellor of the Exchequer]] of the United Kingdom and a friend of Rothschild from school and university. It was reported that [[Peter Mandelson]] had maintained private contacts over several years with Oleg Deripaska{{cite news|url=http://www.timesonline.co.uk/tol/news/politics/article4982163.ece|title=Lord Mandelson and Oleg Deripaska dined together 'a year before they met'|last=Robertson|first=David|date=21 October 2008|newspaper=The Times|location=UK|accessdate=23 October 2008}} News of the contacts sparked criticism because, as European Union Trade Commissioner, Mandelson had been responsible for decision to cut aluminium tariffs from 6 to 3%, a decision that had benefited Deripaska's Company [[RusAl]].{{cite news|url= http://www.moscowtimes.ru/article/1010/42/371829.htm|title=UK Conservatives Linked to Deripaska|date=22 October 2008|newspaper=[[The Moscow Times]] |accessdate= 23 October 2008|deadurl=yes|archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20081126051311/http://www.moscowtimes.ru/article/1010/42/371829.htm|archivedate=26 November 2008}} Mandelson insisted that he had never discussed aluminium tariffs with Deripaska.{{cite news |url=http://www.timesonline.co.uk/tol/news/politics/article4932191.ece|title=Peter Mandelson dogged by his links to Russian oligarch|date=13 October 2008|newspaper=The Times|last2=Charter|first2=David|location=UK|accessdate=23 October 2008|first1=David|last1=Robertson}} On 26 October 2008 the [[Shadow Foreign Secretary]] [[William Hague]] claimed the "whole country" wanted "transparency" about Mandelson's previous meetings with Deripaska. In response, Prime Minister [[Gordon Brown]] said Mandelson's dealings with Deripaska had been "found to be above board".{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/uk_politics/7691678.stm|title=Tories seek Mandelson 'clarity'|date=26 October 2008|publisher=BBC News|accessdate=30 October 2008}} Mandelson said that meeting business figures from "across the range" in emerging economies was part of his brief as EU Trade Commissioner.{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/politics/2008/oct/28/peter-mandelson-oleg-deripaska-corfu|title=Mandelson silent on Deripaska|last=Parfitt|first=Tom|date=28 October 2008|newspaper=The Guardian|location=UK|accessdate=30 October 2008}} On 29 October 2008, while Mandelson was on a ministerial visit to Moscow,{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/politics/2008/oct/29/russia-mandelson|title=Mandelson hails thaw in relations with Moscow|last=Parfitt|first=Tom|date=29 October 2008|work =The Guardian|location=UK|accessdate=30 October 2008}} it was alleged in the British press that [[Valery Pechyonkin|Valery Pechenkin]], the head of security at Deripaska's company Basic Element, had organised a swift entry visa for Mandelson when he turned up in [[Moscow]] to visit Deripaska in 2005.{{cite news|url=http://www.thisislondon.co.uk/standard/article-23579423-details/Veteran+KGB+spy+revealed+as+Deripaska%27s+right-hand+man/article.do|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20081101053919/http://www.thisislondon.co.uk/standard/article-23579423-details/Veteran+KGB+spy+revealed+as+Deripaska%27s+right-hand+man/article.do|dead-url=yes|archive-date=1 November 2008|title=Veteran KGB spy revealed as Deripaska's right-hand man|date=29 October 2008|work=[[London Evening Standard]]|accessdate=30 October 2008|df=dmy-all}} ====Paul Manafort==== On 22 March 2017, the [[Associated Press]] published a report alleging that [[Paul Manafort]], [[Donald Trump]]'s former presidential campaign manager, negotiated a $10 million annual contract with Deripaska to promote Russian interests in politics, business, and media coverage in Europe and the United States, starting in 2005.{{Cite news|url=https://www.apnews.com/122ae0b5848345faa88108a03de40c5a/Manafort's-plan-to-'greatly-benefit-the-Putin-Government|title=Trump campaign chief linked to Putin interests|last=HORWITZ and DAY|first=|date=22 March 2017|work=Associated Press|accessdate=22 March 2017|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170402165112/https://www.apnews.com/122ae0b5848345faa88108a03de40c5a/Manafort's-plan-to-'greatly-benefit-the-Putin-Government|archive-date=2 April 2017|dead-url=yes}} Both Deripaska and Manafort have confirmed to have worked together in the past,{{Cite news |url=https://www.yahoo.com/news/know-paul-manafort-links-oleg-224806634.html|title=What We Know About Paul Manafort's Links to Oleg Deripaska and the Kremlin|accessdate=5 April 2017|language=en-US}} but rejected the contents of the AP story. Manafort argued that his work had been inaccurately presented, and that there was nothing “inappropriate or nefarious" about it.{{Cite news|url=http://thehill.com/policy/international/russia/326170-russian-billionaire-i-didnt-aid-putin-with-manafort|title=Russian billionaire denies aiding Putin with Manafort|last=Hensch|first=Mark|date=28 March 2017|work=TheHill|accessdate=2 June 2017}} Responding to the allegations, on 28 March 2017, Deripaska published open letters in the print editions of ''[[The Washington Post]]'' and ''[[The Wall Street Journal]]'', in which he denied having signed a $10 million contract with Manafort in order to benefit the [[Russia under Vladimir Putin|Putin government]].{{Cite web|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/politics/russian-manafort-client-willing-to-speak-to-congress/2017/03/28/1add6c1a-13e9-11e7-bb16-269934184168_story.html|title=Russian Manafort client: Willing to speak to Congress|website=Washington Post| accessdate=5 April 2017}} He also stated his willingness to testify before the [[United States Congress]] to dispel these allegations,{{Cite web|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/politics/russian-manafort-client-willing-to-speak-to-congress/2017/03/28/1add6c1a-13e9-11e7-bb16-269934184168_story.html|title=Russian Manafort client: Willing to speak to Congress|website=Washington Post|accessdate=5 April 2017}}
{{Cite news |url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/americas/russian-billionaire-oleg-deripaska-paul-manafort-ties-donald-trump-campaign-manager-us-congress-a7655291.html|title=Russian billionaire with ties to Trump’s ex-campaign manager says he is willing to testify before Congress|date=29 March 2017|work= The Independent|accessdate=5 April 2017|language=en-GB}} and argued that the accusations fall "into the negative context of current US-Russian relations."{{Cite news|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/americas/russian-billionaire-oleg-deripaska-paul-manafort-ties-donald-trump-campaign-manager-us-congress-a7655291.html|title=Russian billionaire with ties to Trump's ex-campaign manager says he is willing to testify before Congress|date=29 March 2017|work=The Independent|accessdate=4 April 2017|language=en-GB}} According to Congressional sources cited by ''[[The New York Times]]'', lawmakers declined Deripaska's request, after it emerged that he had asked for immunity. Unnamed officials argued that "immunity agreements create complications for federal criminal investigators".{{Cite news|url= https://www.nytimes.com/2017/05/26/us/politics/oleg-deripaska-paul-manafort.html|title=Russian Once Tied to Trump Aide Seeks Immunity to Cooperate With Congress|last=Meier|first=Barry|date=26 May 2017|work=The New York Times|accessdate=2 June 2017|last2=Drucker|first2=Jesse|language=en-US|issn=0362-4331}} On 15 May 2017, Deripaska filed a defamation and libel lawsuit against the [[Associated Press]] in a [[United States District Court for the District of Columbia|U.S. District Court in D.C.]], arguing that{{Cite web|url=http://www.politico.com/f/?id=0000015c-0e98-de0a-a15e-1f9900d90000|title=''Oleg V. Deripaska v. The Associated Press''|last=|first=|publisher=[[United States District Court for the District of Columbia]]|date=15 May 2017|accessdate=27 May 2017}}
{{Cite web|url=http://fortune.com/2017/05/16/donald-trump-paul-manafort-campaign-ap-lawsuit |title=Russian Magnate Sues AP Over Story on Trump Campaign Ties|website=Fortune|accessdate=22 May 2017}} the outlet's report falsely claimed that Deripaska had signed a contract with Manafort to advance the goals of the Russian government.{{Cite news|url=http://www.politico.com/blogs/under-the-radar/2017/05/15/russian-oligarch-deripaska-manafort-238419|title=Russian oligarch Deripaska sues AP for libel| work=[[Politico]]|accessdate=22 May 2017}} However, the lawsuit was dismissed in October 2017 on the grounds that Deripaska had not disputed "any material facts" in the story by the Associated Press.{{cite web|url=https://www.rferl.org/a/russia-rybkagate-rolls-on-sex-lies-instagram-deripaska-prikhodko/29031221.html|title=Sex, Lies, And Instagram: Russia's 'Rybkagate' Rolls On|website=RadioFreeEurope/RadioLiberty|accessdate=5 March 2018}} During the [[United States presidential election, 2016|2016 Presidential campaign]], Manafort, via [[Kiev]]-based operative [[Konstantin Kilimnik]], offered to provide briefings on political developments to Deripaska, though there is no evidence that the briefings took place.{{cite news |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/politics/manafort-offered-to-give-russian-billionaire-private-briefings-on-2016-campaign/2017/09/20/399bba1a-9d48-11e7-8ea1-ed975285475e_story.html |date=20 September 2017 |title=Manafort offered to give Russian billionaire ‘private briefings’ on 2016 campaign |first=Tom |last=Hamburger |first2=Rosalind S. |last2=Helderman |first3=Carol D. |last3=Leonnig |first4=Adam |last4=Entous |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170921003301/https://www.washingtonpost.com/politics/manafort-offered-to-give-russian-billionaire-private-briefings-on-2016-campaign/2017/09/20/399bba1a-9d48-11e7-8ea1-ed975285475e_story.html |archive-date=21 September 2017 |publisher=''[[The Washington Post]]''}}{{cite news |publisher=''[[Politico]]'' |title=Manafort used Trump campaign account to email Ukrainian operative |first=Josh |last=Dawsey |date=20 September 2017 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170921003929/http://www.politico.com/story/2017/09/20/paul-manafort-trump-campaign-email-ukrainian-operative-242949 |archive-date=21 September 2017 |url=http://www.politico.com/story/2017/09/20/paul-manafort-trump-campaign-email-ukrainian-operative-242949}} Behaviors such as these were seen as an attempt by Manafort to please an oligarch tied to Putin's government.{{cite web|url=https://www.theatlantic.com/politics/archive/2017/10/emails-suggest-manafort-sought-approval-from-putin-ally-deripaska/541677 |title=Did Manafort Use Trump to Curry Favor With a Putin Ally? Emails turned over to investigators detail the former campaign chair's efforts to please an oligarch tied to the Kremlin. |author=[[Julia Ioffe]] and [[Franklin Foer]] |date=2 October 2017 |work=[[The Atlantic]] |access-date=3 October 2017}} ==== Navalny video ==== In February 2018, [[Alexei Navalny]] published a video about a meeting between Deripaska and Deputy Prime Minister of Russia [[Sergei Eduardovich Prikhodko]] on a yacht traveling near Norway. According to Navalny, Deripaska probably served as a middle man between the Russian government represented by Prikhodko and Paul Manafort during [[Russian interference in the 2016 United States elections]]. Prikhodko denied the allegations, accusing Navalny of "mixing the facts" about his "friend" Deripaska, [[Donald Trump]] and [[Paul Manafort]], while also voicing his wish to have talk with Navalny as a "man with a man".{{Cite web|url=https://www.rbc.ru/politics/09/02/2018/5a7dc6479a7947a4be81bebb|title=Вице-премьер Приходько заявил о желании ответить Навальному по-мужски|publisher=РБК|accessdate=10 February 2018}}{{Cite news|accessdate=10 February 2018|language=ru-RU|work=Meduza|title=Роскомнадзор потребовал от «Медиазоны» и «Радио Свобода» удалить фотографии из новости про Дерипаску, Приходько и Рыбку|url=https://meduza.io/news/2018/02/09/roskomnadzor-potreboval-ot-mediazony-udalit-fotografii-iz-novosti-pro-deripasku-prihodko-i-rybku}}{{Cite news|accessdate=10 February 2018|title=Вице-премьер Приходько хочет ответить Навальному по-мужски|url=https://ura.news/news/1052323171}} A day after the video was published the [[Roskomnadzor]] added the video to the [[Federal List of Extremist Materials]], thus making accessing the video illegal for all Russian citizens.{{Cite news|accessdate=10 February 2018|date=10 February 2018|language=ru-RU|work=Interfax.ru|title=Суд включил в реестр запрещенной информации фильм ФБК о Дерипаске и Приходько|url=http://www.interfax.ru/russia/599352}} It also ordered [[YouTube]] to remove seven videos and [[Instagram]] to take down 14 points that were cited in the investigation; neither YouTube nor Instagram had responded as of 12 February 2018. According to a Roskomnadzor representative who spoke to ''[[Vedomosti]]'', a "court injunction of this sort against content hosted on Instagram and YouTube is unprecedented for Russia". The ''New York Times'' noted that this may presage a "more aggressive approach by the Russian government" to control online activities.{{cite news|last1=Luxmoore|first1=Matthew|title=Russia Threatens to Block YouTube and Instagram, After Complaints From an Oligarch|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2018/02/12/world/europe/russia-youtube-instagram-navalny.html|accessdate=13 February 2018| work= New York Times|date=12 February 2018}} ''The New York Times'' reported on 5 March 2018, that [[:uk:Настя Рибка|Anastasia Vashukevich]], a Belarusian national currently incarcerated in [[Bangkok]], claims to have over 16 hours of audio recordings she says could shed light on possible Russian interference in American elections. She is offering the recordings to American authorities in exchange for asylum, to avoid extradition to Belarus. Vashukevich claims to be close to Deripaska and asserts the recordings include him discussing the 2016 presidential election with associates Vashukevich did not name. "Deripaska had a plan about elections," ''The New York Times'' quoted Vashukevich as saying. She stated that some of the recorded conversations, which she asserts were made in August 2016, included three individuals who spoke fluent English and whom she believed were Americans. ''The New York Times'' reported that her claims might be easily dismissed were it not for the Navalny video.{{cite web|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2018/03/05/world/asia/nastya-rybka-trump-putin.html|title=Escort Says Audio Recordings Show Russian Meddling in U.S. Election|first=Richard C.|last=Paddock|date=5 March 2018|publisher=|accessdate=5 March 2018|via=NYTimes.com}} === U.S. sanctions === In April 2018, the United States imposed sanctions on him and 23 other Russian nationals.{{cite web |url=https://www.treasury.gov/resource-center/sanctions/OFAC-Enforcement/Pages/20180406.aspx |title=Ukraine-/Russia-related Designations and Identification Update|author= |date=6 April 2018 |website=[[United States Department of the Treasury]] |publisher= |accessdate=6 April 2018 |language=}}{{cite web |url=https://meduza.io/news/2018/04/06/ssha-vveli-sanktsii-protiv-36-rossiyskih-biznesmenov |title=США ввели санкции против семи российских олигархов и 17 чиновников из «кремлевского списка» |trans-title=The US imposed sanctions against seven Russian oligarchs and 17 officials from the "Kremlin list" |author= |date=6 April 2018 |website=[[Meduza]] |publisher= |accessdate=6 April 2018 |language=ru}} In the statement from the [[United States Department of the Treasury]] it was stated that Deripaska "has been accused of threatening the lives of business rivals, illegally wiretapping a government official, and taking part in extortion and racketeering". According to the US treasury statement there are allegations that Deripaska ordered the murder of a businessman, and had links to a Russian organized crime group.{{cite web |url=https://home.treasury.gov/news/press-releases/sm0338 |title=Treasury Designates Russian Oligarchs, Officials, and Entities in Response to Worldwide Malign Activity|author= |date=6 April 2018 |website=[[United States Department of the Treasury]] |publisher= |accessdate=11 April 2018 |language=}} == Personal life == Deripaska was married to Polina Yumasheva, the daughter of [[Boris Yeltsin]]'s top adviser [[Valentin Yumashev]] and stepdaughter of Yeltsin's daughter [[Tatyana Yumasheva|Tatyana]]. While Yeltsin was president, Deripaska's close ties put him in Yeltsin's inner circle, dubbed "The Family".{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2006/08/20/business/yourmoney/20oligarch.html|title=Out of Siberia, a Russian Way to Wealth|last=Kramer|first=Andrew E.|date=20 August 2006|work=The New York Times|accessdate=2 June 2017|language=en-US|issn=0362-4331}}
{{Cite news|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/europe/7063201/Boris-Yeltsins-daughter-attacks-Vladimir-Putin.html|title=Boris Yeltsin's daughter attacks Vladimir Putin|last=Osborn|first=Andrew|work=Telegraph.co.uk|accessdate=2 June 2017|language=en}} In 2018, several Russian media reported that Deripaska and Yumasheva got divorced. The Deripaskas have two children: a son, Pyotr (born 2001), and daughter, Maria (born 2003).{{cite news|title=Блоги / Эхо-рейтинг: Полина Дерипаска| url=http://echo.msk.ru/blog/echo_rating/850130-echo/|accessdate=25 May 2017|work=Echo Moscow|language=ru}}
{{cite news|title=Президент "Русал" Олег Дерипаска. Биография|url=https://ria.ru/spravka/20141118/1033854288.html|accessdate=25 May 2017|work=RIA Novosti|date=18 November 2014|language=ru}} Deripaska practices yoga, swimming, horseback riding, and hiking. His favorite pets are dogs. At his home near Moscow, he has seven horses and six dogs. In March 2018, it was reported that Deripaska had successfully purchased [[Cypriot citizenship]] in 2017 under Cyprus' "golden visa" that generates billions of revenue for the island nation. According to documents seen by ''[[The Guardian]]'', Deripaska's first attempt to become a citizen of a country in the EU was unsuccessful because of an preliminary inquiry into his activities in Belgium. The inquiry was dismissed in 2016. === Net worth === In 2008, ''Forbes'' estimated his wealth at US$28 billion, making him the then ninth richest man in the world.{{cite news|url=https://www.forbes.com/lists/2008/10/billionaires08_Oleg-Deripaska_UCP9.html |title=#9 Oleg Deripaska Forbes |work=Forbes |date=11 February 2008 |accessdate=14 May 2011}} In 2009, Deripaska's ranking fell to a ranking of No. 164, with ''Forbes'' stating: "[H]e may not withstand collapsing markets and heavy debts".{{cite news| url=https://www.forbes.com/lists/2009/10/billionaires-2009-richest-people_Oleg-Deripaska_UCP9.html | work=Forbes | title=#164 Oleg Deripaska – The World's Billionaires 2009 | date=11 March 2009}} In 2010, however, his estimated $10.7 billion fortune allowed him to rise to No. 57 of the World's Billionaires list.{{cite news|url=https://www.forbes.com/lists/2010/10/billionaires-2010_Oleg-Deripaska_UCP9.html |title=The World's Billionaires 2010, Forbes |work=Forbes |date= 12 February 2010 |accessdate=14 May 2011}} According to ''Forbes'' magazine, he removed the heads of his two largest companies and personally negotiated with the Russian government, banks, and other creditors to restructure his loan obligations.{{cite web|title=Oleg Deripaska|url=https://www.forbes.com/profile/oleg-deripaska/}} Deripaska himself in 2007 was reported to have consistently said that the estimate of his wealth was exaggerated, that it did not completely account for the amount of debt he incurred, and that he should be ranked far below the top ten on the list of the Russian billionaires.{{cite news|first=Luke|last= Harding|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2007/feb/24/business.russia |title=How metals and a ruthless streak put Russian patriot at top of the rich list |work=The Guardian |location=UK |accessdate=14 May 2011 |date=24 February 2007}} Deripaska has owned the [[Herbert Haft|Haft mansion]] near [[Embassy Row]] in [[Washington, D.C.]], through a company incorporated in Delaware since 2006.{{cite web| Its members have full ownership of the [[Porsche SE]] automobile company and majority voting rights over [[Volkswagen AG]], the biggest automaker in the world. Ferdinand Porsche was born to a German-speaking family of [[Maffersdorf]], [[Bohemia]], son of Anton Porsche (1845-1908) and Anna Ehrlich. The [[Sudeten Germans|Sudeten German]] surname ''Porsche'' can be traced to the 18th century in the area of Reichenberg (now [[Liberec]]), Bohemia.baptism of Joannes Josephus (Wenzel) Porsche on 16 July 1777 in Neuharzdorf, Reichenberg parish, son of Antonius Porsche ''Tibialifex'' (stocking-maker) and of M. Elisabeth. [https://familysearch.org/pal:/MM9.3.1/TH-1951-20278-4092-23?cc=1804263&wc=M97D-G4M:1493481211 Liberec Baptisms (Křty) 1771-1780 (v. page.title: Restatement of the Law of Agency, Third

revision.text:
The '''Restatement of the Law of Agency''' (3rd edn, 2006) is a set of principles issued by the [[American Law Institute]], intended to clarify the prevailing opinion on how the law of [[agency (law)|agency]] stands in 2006.
==Definition of agency== para 1.01, "Agency is the fiduciary relationship that arises when one person (a 'principal') manifests assent to another person (an 'agent') that the agent shall act on the principal's behalf and subject to the principal's control, and the agent manifests or otherwise consents so to act."
==See also== *[[Restatement of the law]] *[[United States labor law]]
[[Category:Agency law]] [[Category:Legal treatises]]
{{US-law-stub}}

{{BLP primary sources|date=October 2010}} [[Image:Ron Dembo.jpg|right|thumb|Ron Dembo in 2006]]
'''Ron S. Dembo''' is one of the world's leading authorities in [[risk management]], both as an academic and in business, having founded Algorithmics Inc. He is also the Founder and CEO of Zerofootprint, a [[cleantech]] software and services company. He is the author of three books and numerous technical papers.
The Zerofootprint Foundation was founded in 2005 to engage communities everywhere in the battle against climate change. Its mission is to apply technology, design and risk management to the massive reduction of our environmental footprint.<ref> {{cite news |newspaper = Canadian Business Online |date = 2009-09-04 |title = Q&A Profit 100: Dr. Ron Dembo, founder of Zerofootprint |url = http://www.canadianbusiness.com/entrepreneur/managing/article.jsp?content=20090903_113410_5040 }}{{dead link|date=December 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref> It pursues causes that uphold values of sustainable development, risk management, research, and advocacy. The Foundation initiatives involve government (Federal, Provincial and Municipal), educators (universities, elementary and middle schools) and other not-for-profit organizations. Geographical and societal barriers do not limit its vision. Zerofootprint came in first place and won Gold in the Climate Change category at the [[Canadian Environment Awards]] in 2008.<ref> {{cite web |url = http://www.zerofootprintfoundation.org/press/single/canadian-environment-awards-announces-winners-for-2008/#continuedReading |title = Canadian Environment Awards announces winners for 2008 |accessdate = 2010-10-29 |deadurl = yes |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20101112124253/http://www.zerofootprintfoundation.org/press/single/canadian-environment-awards-announces-winners-for-2008/#continuedReading |archivedate = 2010-11-12 |df = }}</ref> Zerofootprint operates both in the for-profit and charitable domains through two entities, Zerofootprint Software and the Zerofootprint Foundation using shared technology. In 2009, Dembo also established the ZEROprize, a one million dollar prize for a design to retrofit a concrete building built between 1945 and 1990.<ref> {{cite news |date=2009-09-26 |title=ZEROprize for green buildings Traditional cities leak energy. But a new prize offers incentive for change |first=Tom |last=Dyckhoff |newspaper=The Times |url=http://entertainment.timesonline.co.uk/tol/arts_and_entertainment/visual_arts/architecture_and_design/article6849035.ece }}</ref>
Prior to founding Zerofootprint, Dembo was the Founder, CEO, and President of [[Algorithmics Inc.|Algorithmics Incorporated]], growing it from a start-up to the largest [[enterprise risk management]] software company in the world, with offices in fifteen countries and over 70% of the world’s top 100 banks as clients. Algorithmics was consistently voted as one of the top 50 best-managed companies in Canada ( https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Algorithmics_Inc{{Dead link|date=August 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}. )
Dembo had a ten-year academic career at [[Yale University]], where he was cross-appointed between the Department of Computer Science and the School of Management. He has published over sixty technical papers{{Citation needed|date=September 2007}} on finance and [[mathematical optimization]], and holds a number of patents {https://patents.justia.com/inventor/ron-s-dembo} in [[computational finance]].
In May 2007, Dembo was made a lifetime [[Fields Institute]] Fellow. This fellowship is awarded to individuals who have made outstanding contributions to the Fields Institute, its programs, and to the Canadian mathematical community. In July 2007, Dembo was inducted as a charter member of the Risk Who’s Who. Dembo’s alma mater, the [[University of Waterloo]], honoured Dembo with a Lifetime Achievement Award in 2007. He is also a member of the University of Waterloo's Deans Advisory Council in the Faculty of Environment, and a member of the Board of Advisors to the President at the [[Ontario College of Art and Design University]].
Dr. Dembo is also an advisor to the Board at [[Mount Sinai Hospital, Toronto]], and is a member of the Board of Governors of University of Toronto’s [[NSERC|Natural Sciences and Engineering Research Council]] program. In 2009, Dr. Dembo was appointed to the Steering Committee of the [[United Nations Human Settlements Programme#World Urban Campaign|World Urban Campaign]], coordinated by UN-Habitat. He also recently received a [[Green Toronto Award]] from the City of Toronto for his work with Zerofootprint,<ref> {{cite web |url = http://www.toronto.ca/greentorontoawards/2009/finalists.htm |title = Green Toronto Awards Winners and Finalists |accessdate = 2010-12-09 |deadurl = yes |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20110607114046/http://www.toronto.ca/greentorontoawards/2009/finalists.htm |archivedate = 2011-06-07 |df = }}</ref> as well as receiving a Certificate of Recognition, [[Champion of Green]] from the Government of Ontario.<ref> {{cite web |url = http://www.zerofootprint.net/about-zerofootprint-software/management-team |title = Management Team |deadurl = yes |archiveurl = https://archive.is/20100501022455/http://www.zerofootprint.net/about-zerofootprint-software/management-team |archivedate = 2010-05-01 |df = }}</ref>
Dembo is the author of three books: ''Seeing Tomorrow: Rewriting the Rules of Risk'', co-authored with Andrew Freeman, published in April 1998; ''Upside Downside: Simple Rules of Risk Management for the Smart Investor'', co-authored with [[Daniel Stoffman]], published in March 2006; and ''Everything You Wanted to Know About Offsetting But Were Afraid to Ask'', co-authored with [[Clive Davidson]] and released in May 2007.
He holds a [[PhD]] Operations Research, [[University of Waterloo]] (1975); an [[MSc]] Chemical Engineering, [[Technion]] (1972); and a [[BSc]] [[Chemical Engineering]], [[University of the Witwatersrand]] (1969).

'''Shareholder rebellion''' occurs when the owners of a corporation work to throw out management or oppose their decisions. Shareholder rebellion may occur at a [[annual general meeting]] or through a [[proxy battle]]. Shareholders may also threaten to collapse a firm's stock price through concentrated selling.<ref>{{citation|title=Liquidity versus Control: The Institutional Investor as Corporate Monitor|author=John C. Coffee, Jr.|publisher=Columbia Law Review|volume=91|number=6|date=Oct 1991|pages=1277–1368|jstor=1123064}}</ref> In 1998, the [[Rockefeller family]] led a shareholder revolt against [[Exxon]] over its [[climate change]] policy.<ref>{{cite news| url=https://www.theguardian.com/business/2008/may/19/exxonmobil.oil | location=London | work=The Guardian | title=Exxon facing shareholder revolt over approach to climate change | date=2008-05-19 | first=Andrew | last=Clark}}</ref> In 2005, [[Michael Eisner]] retired after [[Walt Disney]]'s nephew, [[Roy E. Disney|Roy Disney]], led a shareholder revolt, claiming Eisner was a [[micromanager]] who had caused a creative [[brain drain]].<ref>{{cite news| url=http://seattletimes.nwsource.com/html/businesstechnology/2011312298_iger14.html | work=The Seattle Times | title=Brain-eating zombies invade Disney in Iger plan to win boy fans | first1=Seth | last1=Lubove | first2=Andy | last2=Fixmer | date=2010-03-13}}</ref> In 2010, [[British Petroleum]]<ref>http://priceofoil.org/2010/02/08/now-bp-faces-shareholder-revolt-over-tar-sands/</ref> and [[Shell (company)|Shell]] faced a shareholder revolt over their [[Canadian tar sands]] policy.<ref>{{cite news| url=https://www.theguardian.com/business/2010/jan/18/shell-shareholders-fury-tar-sands | location=London | work=The Guardian | title=Shell faces shareholder revolt over Canadian tar sands project | date=2010-01-18 | first=Terry | last=MacAlister}}</ref>
Recently, shareholder rebellions have occurred over the issue of [[executive compensation]] at [[Cable & Wireless Worldwide|Cable and Wireless]]<ref>{{cite news| url=https://www.theguardian.com/business/2010/mar/11/cable-and-wireless-pay-shareholder-protest | location=London | work=The Guardian | title=Cable & Wireless facing shareholder revolt over executive pay | date=2010-03-11 | first=Richard | last=Wachman}}</ref> and Shell;<ref>{{cite news| url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2010/02/16/shell-shareholder-rebelli_n_463817.html | work=Huffington Post | title=Shell Shareholder 'Rebellion' Leads To New Limits On Executive Pay, Bonuses | date=2010-02-16}}</ref> Shell in response unveiled a plan to curb executive compensation and bonuses.<ref>https://finance.yahoo.com/news/Shell-unveils-plans-to-curb-apf-853987459.html?x=0</ref> According to some analysts, [[institutional shareholders]] have been lax about holding management accountable because they were concentrating on picking correct stocks rather than protecting their interests in the stocks they owned.<ref>{{cite news| url=http://blogs.reuters.com/great-debate/2009/10/27/time-for-a-shareholder-revolt/ | work=Reuters | title=Time for a shareholder revolt | date=2009-10-27}}</ref> With many firms showing poor performance, shareholder revolts are becoming more common.<ref>{{cite news| url=http://business.timesonline.co.uk/tol/business/industry_sectors/banking_and_finance/article6256636.ece | location=London | work=The Times | title=To arms investors Its a shareholder revolt | first1=Jenny | last1=Davey | first2=James | last2=Ashton | date=2009-05-10}}</ref>
==History== {{More information|Dutch East India Company}} On 24 January 1609, Amsterdam-based [[businessman]] [[Isaac Le Maire]] filed a petition against the [[Dutch East India Company]] (VOC), marking the first recorded expression of [[shareholder activism]] or shareholder rebellion.<ref>Frentrop, Paul (2009). ''The First Known Shareholder Activist: The Colorful Life and Times of Isaac le Maire (1559–1624)'', in Frentrop/Jonker/Davis 2009, 11–26</ref><ref>Frentrop, Paul; Jonker, Joost; Davis, S. (ed.), (2009). ''Shareholder Rights at 400: Commemorating Isaac Le Maire and the First Recorded Expression of Investor Advocacy'' (The Hague: Remix Business Communications, 2009)</ref><ref>Gelderblom, Oscar; De Jong, Abe; Jonker, Joost (2010). ''Putting Le Maire into Perspective: Business Organization and the Evolution of Corporate Governance in the Dutch Republic, 1590–1610'', in J. Koppell, ed., ''Origins of Shareholder Advocacy''. (New York: Palgrave Macmillan)</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://corpgov.net/2011/10/unfi-goes-virtual-only-shareowners-should-protest/ |title=Will UNFI Go Virtual-Only Again? Not if Shareowners Just Say No |publisher=CorpGov.net |last=McRitchie |first=James |date=6 Oct 2011 |accessdate=28 Dec 2016 }}</ref><ref>Mueller, Dennis C. (ed.), (2012). ''The Oxford Handbook of Capitalism'', p. 333. (New York: Oxford University Press)</ref><ref>Hansmann, Henry; Pargendler, Mariana (2013). ''The Evolution of Shareholder Voting Rights: Separation of Ownership and Consumption''. (Yale Law Journal, Vol. 123, pp. 100–165, 2014)</ref>
